security_audit.summary: This skill is a pure documentation and prompt-based skill containing ADR templates and guidelines. All static findings are false positives. SKILL.md contains only documentation text, templates, and example markdown. No executable code, scripts, network calls, cryptographic operations, or file operations are present. The skill is completely safe for publication.

content.user_title: Document architectural decisions with ADR templates
content.value_statement: Technical teams forget why decisions were made. This skill helps create Architecture Decision Records that capture context, alternatives, and trade-offs for future team members and your future self.
actual_capabilities: Compare technical alternatives with structured analysis
Document decision context including constraints and trade-offs
Create ADR index and numbering system
Maintain decision status tracking (Proposed, Accepted, Deprecated)
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Does not integrate with external ADR tools
Does not auto-generate diagrams or visualizations
Does not validate decisions against project requirements

use_cases.title: Record architectural choices
use_cases.description: Document major technology selections with full context for future reference and team alignment.

use_cases.title: Reduce onboarding time
use_cases.description: Help new team members understand why technical decisions were made without asking veteran developers.

use_cases.title: Track infrastructure decisions
use_cases.description: Record deployment strategies, CI/CD choices, and infrastructure-as-code decisions with clear rationale.

prompt_templates.title: New Technology ADR
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ADR for choosing between [Technology A] and [Technology B] for our [use case]. Include context, alternatives compared, decision made, and trade-offs.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Pattern ADR
prompt_templates.prompt: Write an ADR documenting our decision to use [architecture pattern] for [project type]. Include why other patterns were rejected and expected impacts.

prompt_templates.title: Deprecation ADR
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ADR for deprecating [legacy system]. Include migration path, timeline, and reasons for deprecation.

prompt_templates.title: ADR Index Entry
prompt_templates.prompt: Add this ADR to our index with title, current status, and date. Format it for the README.md index table.

output_examples.input: Create an ADR for choosing PostgreSQL over MongoDB for our project with user data and transactions.
output: Context: User-project relationships, ACID compliance needed, complex queries required
Alternatives: MongoDB (flexible schema, horizontal scaling) vs PostgreSQL (ACID, JOINs, JSON support)
Trade-offs: PostgreSQL offers stronger consistency; MongoDB offers easier horizontal scaling

output_examples.input: Write an ADR for adopting microservices architecture for our e-commerce platform.
output: Context: Monolith scaling limitations, team autonomy needed, independent deployments required
Alternatives: Modular monolith, service-oriented architecture, full microservices
Trade-offs: Microservices offer independence but add operational complexity

output_examples.input: Create an ADR for implementing JWT authentication instead of session-based auth.
output: Context: Mobile API access needed, stateless architecture preferred, reduced server storage
Alternatives: Session cookies, OAuth 2.0, API keys
Trade-offs: JWT offers statelessness but requires careful token management and refresh logic

best_practices: Write ADRs when the decision is fresh, not months later when context is lost
Include all considered alternatives, not just the winner, to show deliberate analysis
Be honest about trade-offs and risks, not just the benefits of your choice
anti_patterns: Writing decisions after implementation without capturing the pre-decision debate
Using ADR as documentation only for successful decisions, not failed experiments
Leaving decisions in Proposed status without ever accepting or rejecting them

faq.question: What tools support ADR workflows?
faq.answer: adr-tools CLI, adr-log npm package, and Git-based workflows. This skill provides templates that work with any approach.

faq.question: How detailed should an ADR be?
faq.answer: Include enough context for someone unfamiliar with the discussion to understand why the decision was made and its implications.

faq.question: When should I create an ADR?
faq.answer: Create ADRs for decisions that affect multiple components, require significant effort to reverse, or involve non-obvious trade-offs.

faq.question: How do I handle superseded decisions?
faq.answer: Mark the original ADR as Superseded by [new ADR number] and link to the new decision. Keep the old ADR for historical context.

faq.question: Is my data stored anywhere?
faq.answer: No. ADRs are generated as text output. You save them to your own repository. Nothing leaves your machine.

faq.question: How is this different from design documents?
faq.answer: ADRs focus specifically on the decision and its rationale, not implementation details. They are intentionally concise and structured.
